content.description:
Mostly cruiser climbing in the 5.6 range with the exception of one 15 foot section of 5.10 climbing. A very unique and enjoyable stroll across most of the cliff. How cool is that? Start on the far right side of the cliff. Go to the right end of Moe Wall, walk up the right side and flake your rope on a nice ledge between 3 maples and one spruce about 20 feet above the base.
Pitch 1 - Start up on gorgeous stone making a high angle traverse toward the middle of the middle of Moe Wall, if that makes sense. From the mid point traverse horizontally across the rest of Moe Wall and gain the tree ledge of the Main Wall. Stop and belay at the first bolted anchor.
Pitch 2 - Continue traversing right across the main wall. Step down where the Main Wall meets the X Wall. Ascend the Dance Platform then step left to the Magic X bolted anchor and belay.
Pitch 3 - Make one move down then head toward the corner of 50 Mission clipping some bolts along the way. Tenuous moves with poor feet near the overlap will lead you to the corner where it eases off once again. Continue on easy ground to the last bolted station on the Green Zone Wall.
You can rap to the ground from here with one 60 meter rope but it is a stretcher. Excellent gear throughout. Bolt protected crux. Bolted anchors.

climbs.name: Ain't Nobody Here But Us Chickens

content.description:
Unlock a sequence to get to the bolt (one small piece of gear between the bolt and the ground) then continue up into a series of cracks and pockets to the top.

Start just right of Let The Good Times Roll on a ten foot wide blank face directly below a bolt. Rap the route.
Single rack to 2".  Bolted rap station.

The first crux is near the bottom of the first pitch getting established into the bigger cracks. Gear is a little tricky and there are some not so reassuring pinches. A bolt protects a slight run out. Second pitch is low fifth to the tree ledge. There is a one move wonder off the tree ledge that goes at 5.7 then it is easy again. This is a great line with tons of variety and will feel like a longer climb.

Start is the next line right of What's the Use in Getting Sober.  Take the line that falls just right of the spruce tree on the wall.  Various options for getting down.  Three raps on a single 60 meter rope.
Single rack to 4". The 4 is not absolutely necessary but nice. No need to double up if you climb this route in three pitches. One bolt on pitch 1. Bolted anchors. Rap the route.

The first pitch of this route is probably the nicest climbing on the lower pitches of the whole wall. Plenty of gear, easy but fun climbing. The second pitch crux is not far off the belay ledge. There is gear but it is below a couple of hard moves so it can be exciting. There is one more tricky run out section before you get to the top. Pitch 1: Start just right of the middle of the wall opposite of the Moe Wall sign. Climb up to the corner of a large sloping ledge and two bolt anchor. 5.5 G 90’
Pitch 2: Move to the back of the ledge on the left and climb a series of corner cracks. Continue straight up and arrive at the tree ledge. 5.9 R 85’ Single rack to 3". There is a bolted rap station on a ledge after the first pitch.

climbs.name: Four Eyed Moe
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes, Denise Hamel and Shawn Bethune

content.description:
Nothing really cruxy on this.  Super fun easy climbing.


Pitch 1: The route is found just left of the middle of Moe Wall. Climb up through a series of cracks, pockets and juggy pinches to a nice ledge with a two bolt rap station. 5.5 PG 90'

Pitch 2: Continue up on a series of ledges that look like stairs until you reach the tree ledge. Aim for the tree in the middle of the ledge. Belay here. 5.4 G 85’

Pitch 3: Continue up the back wall of the tree ledge through a series of pockets and cracks to the top of the cliff. 5.5 PG 60’

Single rack to 3" or 4".  Tree anchor or step left to a rappel station.

Climb up some very pleasant cracks and jugs to a two bolt anchor and small ledge. From here climb another pitch directly above (After Midnight) or rap. Generally good gear but one or two slight run outs over very easy climbing.  Some would consider this climb PG.  The crux protects extremely well.

On the far right hand side of the main wall locate a mature Yellow Birch tree growing out of the wall about ten feet above the base. The climb starts down and slightly right of the birch on Five Guys Named Moe or just Moe Wall.
Standard rack to 3".  Bolted rap anchor.

Start on the second stump right of Eat Moe. Follow a discontinuous finger sized crack angling slightly right. Finicky, slightly run out gear for the first 40 feet.

Start on the second stump right of Eat Moe. Follow a discontinuous finger sized crack angling slightly right. Rap the route.
Single rack to 2".  Bolted rap station.

Crux is getting to the bolt.  Tricky run out face climbing will get your motor running.

Start on the right side of the blank face below the last bolt on the wall.  Begin just left of a large Yellow Birch tree.  Climb up to the pocket below the bolt then continue up into a series of cracks and pockets to the top.  Rap the route.
Single rack to 2".  One bolt.  Bolted rap station.

climbs.name: Little Moe
climbs.fa: Mike Parker, Lily Parker and Melissa Parker

content.description:
A splendid route on clean, hard granite. Brilliant movement through varied and unique formations. The gem of the wall. Pitch 1: On the far right hand side of the wall, climb a line of high quality granite beside the large Yellow Birch tree to a stance halfway up the wall and belay at a bolted rap station. 5.6 PG 80’
Pitch 2: Continue up on the cleanest line on the right side of the wall to the top. Tree anchor. 5.6 PG 85’
Several options for rapelling or walking off this route. Single rack to 3". Bolted anchor at first belay.

climbs.name: No Moe
climbs.fa: Mike Parker, Lily Parker and Melissa Parker

content.description:
Crux is down low getting established into the good cracks and then one more slightly difficult part mid way.

This climb is located just right of Little Moe on the far right hand side of the wall.  Climb up to a stance halfway up the wall and belay at a bolted rap station.
Single rack to 3".  Bolted rap station.

From the Too Drunk anchor head up to a short steep crack that angles back after about 20 feet.  Follow the cracks to the top.  Double up on #1 through #3 camalots or run it out.

Climb Im Too Drunk to reach this climb. Rap the route.
Standard rack to 4".  Bolted anchors.

climbs.name: What's The Use in Getting Sober

content.description:
Pleasant movement with excellent rock quality. Some might consider the bottom half of pitch 1 pg but the gear is there and a bolt protects a run out section. After that the gear abounds and the climbing is low fifth class up to a steeper headwall. This is a nice long route that has a lot of variety.

This is the second route on Moe Wall.  Only a few feet to the right of I'm Too Drunk For This.  Look up and locate a Spruce tree growing out of the wall about 75 feet off the ground.  The route climbs a plumb line below the tree but when you reach the tree move around to the left and keep going until you reach a bolted belay.  From the belay head up to a pin.  From there you can go slightly left or right (harder) to reach the top.
Single rack to 4". Double up from 1 to 3 inches unless you are ok with run outs. There is a bolt on pitch 1 and a fixed pin on the crux of pitch 2. Bolted anchors. Rap the route.

As you walk in on the approach trail you will see this wall to the right. This is the tallest part of the cliff. From the ground to the top is about 230 feet. The wall has plenty of cracks but some are flaring so protection can be difficult to find when you really want it. Thankfully the climbing is straight forward and the friction is great.
